bibl.title: Despatch from J.M.Preston to William H. Seward, Janurary 3, 1866
Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

text.body:
<pb facs="20170615_112047"
To Mr. Hem W.Me.Seward, Secretary of State, Washington D.C.
Sir: I have the honor to aacknowledge, since my last, the reciept, from the Dep. of State of despatch No.14, requesting me to continue to act as Vier Com'd Agt. 16th proclamation of president Johnson in relation to N. leardins, Circular in relation to the Am. Geo and State Sec. N.Y. and a copy of "List, of Diplomatic+ Consular offices at".
I reply to note on page 2 of said "List", That The "Meavval" here was printed at "Washington, 1863.
To note on page 56, I reply that "Gaboon" is seriosuly put on page 10, among "Porteguese Ammeins". It should be among French on page 9.
our <pb facs="20170615_112051"
I have no arrivals of vessels to report during the past six months, nor any fees.
During the year 1865 only two American vessels (barike) have entered this part.
There is no material change in the trade. The articles of export ( hory and Barwood) are becoming yearly searcers + dearer; and year by year subject to more more inbutes* competition.
I have the honor to be, SIrr, your obt. Servt. J.M.Preston Vice Comd. Agent.
